title: Seahorses are to be given greater protection from oil drilling after a landmark High Court challenge
text:
Seahorses are to be given greater protection from oil drilling off British coastlines after a landmark High Court challenge.

The Secretary of State and the Oil and Gas Authority permitted exploratory drilling of oil by Corallian Energy Limited in Poole Bay, Dorset in 2018.

But Neil Garrick-Maidment, the founder of the Seahorse Trust, said the species had been put at risk by the drilling, with some found dead, washed up on the shore.

Mr Garrick-Maidment launched a crowdfunded judicial review at the High Court after arguing the application for the oil rig had not looked into the impacts on the environment.

The Government chose not to defend the challenge and instead said they would amend legislation concerning the environmental impact of offshore drilling.

Garrick-Maidment paid tribute to the “many people worldwide” who had supported his case, after £12,000 was raised through a Crowd Justice funding appeal.

Ministers will now carry out a review of the of the Offshore Petroleum Production and Pipe-lines (Assessment of Environmental Effects) Regulations 1999.

They will then make amendments to them following public consultation which applies to all future UK oil rigs.

Mr Garrick-Maidment said the victory will ensure that drilling in UK waters will be subject to proper scrutiny and consultation so that sensitive species - such as seahorses - are protected.
description: Seahorses are to be given greater protection from oil drilling off British coastlines after a landmark High Court challenge.
